author: marybschneider

text: Keeler says the two riverboats in Gary would stay in operation until the changeover to opening a single land-based , and no one would lose their job. The new casino would create 400 new jobs, he says.
author: marybschneider

text: But Keeler says there are risks to this, as Illinois may move a casino to Chicago area near Indiana and the other IN casinos in the Region are strong competitors.
author: marybschneider

text: John Keeler, former state rep and lobbyist for Spectacle Entertainment (Gary casino license), is telling the committee how crappy the casinos/hotel are there and how no one can find them. Relocating will make a world of difference, he argues.
author: marybschneider

text:
Clabber Girl is for SB552.
Like baking soda, it will help Terre Haute rise.

See what I did there?
author: marybschneider

text: Mayor of Anderson also is supporting SB552, saying that city lost many jobs when car manufacturing left. They've got a racino there, and want the added business that live dealers are expected to bring.
author: marybschneider

text: SB552 is Gary and Terre Haute (with an assist from racinos) vs the existing casinos. Who wins? We won't know today, as the Public Policy Committee is taking testimony only, not voting.
author: marybschneider

text: Terre Haute business leader citing 5.2 percent unemployment rate in Indiana, one of the highest in the state. Says SB522 is needed to help the city out of its slump.
author: marybschneider

text: He (I think he is on Terre Haute council) says the casino will do more than they can imagine to help people, urging committee to pass SB552. "Development for our community and Gary is very important."
author: marybschneider

text: I didn't catch his name, but a man with five ISU degrees is up. He lived in Gary, Hammond & East Chicago and now Terre Haute. He says he has a "PhD in streetology" & says he speaks for "the silent majority" of the impoverished. "I want Gary IN, I want Terre Haute IN to succeed."
author: marybschneider

text:
This is the kind of hearing that they should have started at 9 a.m. instead of 3:30.
Just saying.
author: marybschneider

text: Now Terre Haute mayor up saying that the city is ready to get the casino license, one of two Gary has and which they will give up in exchange for getting to move their other boat to land to make room for a port project.
author: marybschneider

text: LOL
author: marybschneider

text: Don't be Bevin. Don't let your kids be like Bevins. Read this: "Chickenpox used to be very common in the US. In the early 1990s, an average of 4 million people got varicella, 10,500 to 13,000 were hospitalized... , and 100 to 150 died each year."
author: marybschneider

text:
Because giving them the vaccine and saving them from an illness that can be far more serious than people remember was just too hard.
This ignorance and attitude is dangerous, especially from a governor.
author: marybschneider

text: SB 552 still going on. The whole "limit your testimony to 4 minutes" thing is like the pirate's code. More of a guideline than a code.
author: marybschneider

text: Holy moly! This thread
author: marybschneider

text: SB 552 cries out for a great Matt Tully column. He lived in and knew The Region, and I think would have nailed this for those of us who only know Gary by reputation, not reality.
author: marybschneider

text: I'm betting that some of the lawmakers start drifting away.
author: marybschneider

text: Now committee is talking about one area that hasn't gotten as much discussion: Sports betting.
author: marybschneider

text: Like former Rep. Charlie Brown, D-Gary, fmr. Sen. Earline Rogers, also D-Gary, is giving the newbies a history lesson on the hard work that went into getting casinos in Gary. "They rewarded us with two licenses in Gary" -- something no other community got.
author: marybschneider

text: Now the great former Sen. Earline Rogers, D-Gary, is up. Says she is usually introduced as "Earline the casino queen."
author: marybschneider

text: Hammond just literally said "slippery slope."
author: marybschneider

text: We were all happy when casino lobbyist John Hammond said he had nothing to add to what a client said. But then committee started peppering Hammond -- a very respected lobbyist for many issues in the Statehouse and an RNC committeeman -- with questions. Lots & lots of questions.
author: marybschneider

text:
I have an answer for that.
No. No they are not.
author: marybschneider

text: We've gone from we could only have casinos in navigable rivers (meaning Indy couldn't qualify), to putting them dockside, to putting them at racetracks without live dealers, to we are now talking about land-based casinos with live dealers at the tracks.
author: marybschneider

text: For those who don't remember, Indiana got riverboats when a D House and R Senate couldn't get budget agreement with a D governor. So they cut this deal putting riverboats and budget in one bill.
author: marybschneider

text: Exactly. Everybody's vote would matter in a way that they don't now. Rs would campaign in downstate Illinois, which they ignore now because they know the EVs will go to Ds. And Ds might not just fly over Indiana.
author: marybschneider

text: Basically the argument against SB552 is slippery slope, unintended consequences, hell in a hand basket.
author: marybschneider

text: Now casino manager for Ameristar up saying Indiana has been a beacon of stability in its business environment. But "unfortunately all this stability" is now at risk due to SB552. Apparently the road to hell is paved with SB552.
author: marybschneider

text: And they certainly never wanted to actually pass a balanced budget when they controlled Congress.
author: marybschneider

text: Veterans never have to say thank you to us. We say thank you to them.
author: marybschneider

text: Whoever said it was one funny guy.
author: marybschneider

text: Hammond chief of staff for mayor now talking, worried about protecting Horseshoe casino there. Moving Gary to land-based says it will "destabilize" the casino situation in the Greater Chicago area, and said Illinois is just panting to plant one by IN border.
author: marybschneider

text: KF-W says Gary is not trying to do this "on the backs of our neighbors."
author: marybschneider

text: Gary Mayor KF-W says that is why they've been "so passionate about the importance of SB 552." For them, it's the development of "a new opportunity" that is aided by moving the casino. "But our focus is on ... new businesses, thousands of jobs and the tax revenue from that."
author: marybschneider

text: Gary Mayor Karen Freeman-Wilson tells House committee that "every day I hear about pot holes, vacant and abandoned buildings, crime.. and the need for jobs." Every day she works with people to solve those issues, she said, and it all goes back to resources, tax dollars.
author: marybschneider

text:
Wonder if this still works.
"Old writer needs $15,000 so she can buy a motor scooter and see the world."
author: marybschneider

text: This is pretty typical in the legislature. Lobbyists play behind the scenes until they see they may be losing.
author: marybschneider

text: Committee is being told how report developing the port would be a huge game-changer for Gary area. I didn't catch his name, (Vickerman?) but he calls this "a transformational issue that will help Chicago" and benefit The Region substantially.
author: marybschneider

text: Vile.
author: marybschneider

text: This was from the mayor of East Chicago, Anthony Copeland.
author: marybschneider

text: From the gambling bill hearing, SB 552
author: marybschneider

text: I don't go to casinos. I was in one once and was horrified by the soulless atmosphere. But Indiana placed its bet long ago; now we are just "haggling over the price," as Churchill once said.
author: marybschneider

text: It's why I don't care about nationwide polls for presidential contests in the final month or so. State polls matter most.
author: marybschneider

text:
An opponent of the bill says "this is about feelings.... This is about the expansion of gaming."
"On whose back are we expanding gaming on? It's the working person," he says.
author: marybschneider

text:
No. The polls showed a majority favored her. And they did.
And I've never yet seen a person answering a poll base their answer on "what the elites want."
author: marybschneider

text:
Rep. Matt Lehman, R-St. Berne, is raising the slippery slope argument, that letting Gary go land based will lead to that elsewhere.
I'm remembering when the legislature was only going to allow scratch-off tickets, no other gambling or lottery. So we've been on the slope.
author: marybschneider

text: Apropos of nothing, I'm remembering the time the very tall Rep. Charlie Brown called the height-challenged Gov. Daniels "Lord Shorty."
author: marybschneider

text: Gary Mayor Karen Freeman-Wilson also will be testifying, trying to move the riverboat casino to land-based so that a port development project can proceed.
author: marybschneider

text: Brown says "I am here with one single mission. that is to see that Gary has the opportunity to move one of its licenses off the water and develop the land where boats currently exist."
author: marybschneider

text: Witnesses are being held to 4 minutes. But the chairman just told former Rep. Charlie Brown he can have all the time he wants "but I can tell you people are going to get hungry."
author: marybschneider

text:
Brown says he is there to talk about Gary, and the need for 
"this economic development project" in that oft-beleaguered city.
author: marybschneider

text: Cool! Former Rep. Charlie Brown, D-Gary, is back in the House, testifying on the gaming bill. He's giving the newbies a history lesson on the history of casinos in Indiana, from riverboats that had to float to the current request for land-based casinos.

text: Usually “special legislation” targets Marion County, such as when they created Unigov without any vote in this county. Rep. Cherrish Pryor, D-Indy, says Indy would love to no longer have special legislation.
author: marybschneider

text:
This bill is about 1 township in St. Joe County.
One township, 300 students.
And just about every legislator has gotten up to talk about it. (Or at least it feels like it.)
DeLaney, D-Indy, says the narrow scope of bill is likely unconstitutional.
author: marybschneider

text:
Debate in House on SB421, school corporation deannexation, is largely about fact that the bill doesn’t apply statewide. 
I’m not taking a stand in this bill, but there are way too many bills that target one area.

text: The “answer”  from Rep. Tim Wesco, said with a grin, was that he looked forward to discussing making it statewide in the future. That doesn’t explain why not statewide now.

text: In the House & just heard a bill author giving a smarmy dodge instead of an answer when a rep asked him why SB421 is “special legislation” that doesn’t affect every county. It’s one of my least favorite things in the legis. Qs deserve serious answers, esp. for bills on final vote
